awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Role of Extracellular H+ in Processing Visual Signals
awd_abstract_narration:
Proper signaling by neurons in the central nervous system is essential in enabling organisms to perceive the world around them and to respond appropriately and adeptly to challenges in their environment.  Glial cells (support cells that wrap and envelop nerve cells and are at least as numerous as the neurons themselves) are known to modulate neuronal signaling, but the molecular mechanism(s) by which they exert their effects is largely unknown.  This work will test the hypothesis that glial cells modify neuronal signaling by altering levels of extracellular acidity, decreasing neurotransmitter  release from neurons.  The research program will be conducted in the context of a unique research and teaching collaboration in which undergraduates and faculty from a primarily undergraduate institution are active participants in testing important fundamental questions in neurobiology in conjunction with students and faculty at several research-intensive universities. 

Using the vertebrate retina as a model system, the study will employ ultra-sensitive self-referencing H+-selective microelectrodes in conjunction with newly developed H+-imaging technologies to measure levels of extracellular H+ from isolated cells and within the intact retina. The ionic and molecular mechanisms that mediate glial cell-induced extracellular acidifications will be examined.  Electrophysiological methods will be used to monitor how glial cell activation alters the flow of neuronal information processing in retinal slices.  The research will help to resolve a current controversy regarding the potential role that changes in extracellular acidity play in retinal function.  These findings also have the potential to answer a long-standing mystery of retinal function - why tonic depolarization of photoreceptors, which occurs in darkness, does not lead to excess release of neurotransmitter and consequent death of neurons by glutamate-induced excitotoxicity.  The results of these studies are likely to have broad implications for neuroscience generally: glial modulation of neurotransmitter release via increases in extracellular H+ may be a widely used mechanism to regulate synaptic strength and prevent glutamate-induced excitotoxicity throughout the nervous system.

por.por_cntn:
Neuronal signaling is fundamental to an organism’s ability to perceive the environment accurately and respond appropriately.  Glial cells, nearly equal in number to neurons in the central nervous system, are known to regulate neuronal signaling, yet the molecular mechanisms mediating this regulation remain unclear. Outcomes of the present study lend support to the hypothesis that glial cells shape the strength of neuronal signaling by regulating levels of extracellular acidity, which will significantly modify neurotransmitter release at synapses. A key broader impact of this work is that most of these studies were carried out by 22 undergraduates from a primarily undergraduate institution. Sixteen of these undergraduates participated in intensified summer research experiences  and presented results at local/regional STEM research symposia, and 15 made contributions that led to co-authorship on peer-reviewed research publications.

        The collection of studies reported here demonstrate that Müller glial cells isolated from vertebrate retina can  act as potent extracellular acidifiers. These studies employed the use of ultra-sensitive self-referencing H+-selective microelectrodes to measure levels of extracellular H+ adjacent to isolated cells as well as cells within the intact retina. Using this approach, we demonstrated that extracellular ATP, known to be a potent activator of glial cells, induces H+ efflux from retinal Müller glial cells.  The ATP-initiated increase in H+ efflux depends on the release of stored of intracellular calcium and consequent upregulation of both sodium-hydrogen exchange and monocarboxylate transport (see schematic figure of this pathway).  We further observed this ATP-mediated effect across a wide breadth of species and glial cell types.  We published five journal manuscripts with an additional two more in development demonstrating that this regulatory mechanism occurs in isolated vertebrate retinal glia across a wide span of species ranging from lamprey to human.  Additionally, we have reported that ATP initiates H+ efflux from glia more broadly across the central nervous system including astrocytes cultured from mouse cortex and hippocampus. 

        We believe our data strongly implicate ATP-mediated H+ release from glial cells as a key neuromodulatory mechanism regulating synaptic transmission in the retina and throughout the brain.  These findings help to resolve current controversies regarding the role that alterations in extracellular acidity play in regulating retinal and neuronal function.  Our results also address a long-standing mystery of retinal function:  why tonic depolarization of photoreceptors, which occurs in darkness, does not lead to excess release of neurotransmitter and consequent death of neurons by glutamate-induced excitotoxicity.  Additionally, our findings point toward glial cell mediated-regulation of extracellular levels of H+ as a prominent and conserved molecular mechanism that is a fundamental and unifying feature across the central nervous system of vertebrates.  We finally suggest that dysregulation of H+ efflux from glial cells may play a key role in such abnormalities and diseases as spreading depression, migraine, epilepsy,and alterations in brain rhythms in addition to significantly affecting visual processing (see doi: 10.3389/fncel.2021.693095).
